sections.1_story: Imagine a city facing frequent traffic jams. The city council receives a report (statement) about the problem and must decide what steps (course of action) to take. In exams, you are given a statement describing a problem and several possible actions. You must judge which actions are logical, practical, and directly address the problem.

ğŸ’¡ Course of Action: A step or decision proposed to solve or address the problem in the statement.
ğŸ’¡ Feasible Action: An action that is practical and can be implemented.
ğŸ’¡ Logical Action: An action that directly addresses the root cause of the problem.
ğŸ’¡ Relevant Action: An action that is connected to the statement and not unrelated.
ğŸ’¡ Drastic Action: An extreme step, often not preferred unless necessary.
ğŸ’¡ Preventive Action: Steps taken to avoid the problem in the future.
ğŸ’¡ Remedial Action: Steps taken to solve the problem after it has occurred.

4_micro_examples: Statement: Increase in road accidents. Action: Enforce stricter traffic rules. (Logical)
Statement: Water shortage in summer. Action: Launch water conservation campaign. (Logical)
Statement: Low attendance in school. Action: Punish all students. (Not logical)
Statement: Pollution in city. Action: Plant more trees. (Logical)
Statement: High electricity bills. Action: Promote LED bulbs. (Logical)
Statement: Frequent thefts. Action: Increase police patrols. (Logical)
Statement: Poor exam results. Action: Reduce syllabus. (Not logical)
Statement: Traffic congestion. Action: Build flyovers. (Logical)
Statement: Littering in parks. Action: Install more dustbins. (Logical)
Statement: Delayed trains. Action: Improve maintenance. (Logical)

actions: Start a public awareness campaign about mosquito control.

actions: Organize extra classes for weak students.
